description.plain:
Born Faheem Najim, T-Pain (short for Tallahassee Pain, a reference to hardship growing up in Tallahassee) has been involved in more than 50 chart-topping singles and is regarded as one of the musicians most responsible for popularizing Auto-Tune.

After breaking away from a 5-member group called Nappy Headz, he quickly rose to fame as a solo artist.

T-Pain has currently released 6 studio albums in the following order: Rappa Ternt Sanga, Epiphany, Thr33 Ringz, RevolveR, OBLiViON , and 1UP.

In 2019, T-Pain won the first season of The Masked Singer as The Monster.

description.plain:
“Buy U A Drank (Shawty Snappin')” is the song that is responsible for associating autotune with T-Pain’s name. The track was the breakout song off his second studio album Epiphany, featuring a short cameo from Yung Joc.

October 2014 T-Pain, in collaboration with NPR tiny desk concerts, performed ‘Buy U A Drank’ without his signature autotune. Turns out he can sing! Like, really really well.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CIjXUg1s5gc

description.plain:
Released on July 29, 2008, “Can’t Believe It” was the lead single for T-Pain’s third studio album, Thr33 Ringz.

The song features Lil Wayne and is the duo’s second collaboration released as a single, following Wayne’s track “Got Money”.

description.plain: “I’m N Luv Wit a Stripper” is a single released by singer T-Pain, taken from his debut album, Rappa Ternt Sanga as the second single from the album. The song was released on December 13, 2005, and it features rapper Mike Jones. It peaked on the Billboard Hot 100 chart at number five and ten on the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs. It also charted in the UK at number 38. In order to eliminate the sexual references in the song, it was remade as “I’m N Luv (Wit a Dancer)”. This is T-Pain’s second top ten single and Mike Jones' first (and his most successful one to date). A remix was also released.

songs.full_title: I'm Sprung by T-Pain
songs.title: I’m Sprung

description.plain:
In an interview with music magazine Billboard, T-Pain talks about the origin of the phrase “I’m sprung”:

I got that word “sprung” from a movie. I think there was a movie called Sprung at that time so then it was like the early ‘90s. It had been a thing already but I didn’t think I was doing anything special or new but that’s just a natural thing for me. People related to me so well. The way I brought across this message was good, my melodies was catchy – all those things just help me tell the story. And I’m sure other people was goin’ through it but too afraid to talk about it I guess at the time but I just thought it was a normal thing because [I was making music] so much. It felt normal as hell to me.

songs.title: Bartender

description.plain: ‘Bartender’ is a song from T-Pain’s second album Epiphany. Featuring Akon, this song peaked at No. 5 on the Billboard Hot 100 Chart. In it, T-Pain breaks up with his girlfriend and goes to a bar where he promptly falls in love with  the bartender.

songs.full_title: 5 O'Clock by T-Pain (Ft. Lily Allen & Wiz Khalifa)
songs.title: 5 O’Clock

description.plain: “5 O'Clock” is the second official single from T-Pain’s fourth studio album, Revolver. Featured on the song as guest vocalists are American rapper Wiz Khalifa. British pop singer Lily Allen’s 2009 single “Who’d Have Known”, is sampled. The song peaked at number ten on the Billboard Hot 100, becoming Allen’s first top ten single in the United States.

songs.full_title: Panda (T-mix) by T-Pain (Ft. Young Cash)
songs.title: Panda (T-mix)

description.plain:
“Panda (T-mix)” is a remix of “Panda” by Desiigner featuring two verses from T-Pain and one from collaborator Young Cash.

The original version of this remix, released on various music platforms only featured one verse from T-Pain and ended with Desiigner’s verse from the original song.  Since then, the song was removed from Spotify and Pain added the version with his second verse to Soundcloud.

songs.full_title: I'm N Luv Wit a Stripper (Remix) by T-Pain (Ft. MJG, Paul Wall, Pimp C, R. Kelly, Too $hort & Twista)
songs.title: I’m N Luv Wit a Stripper (Remix)
songs.title_with_featured: I'm N Luv Wit a Stripper (Remix) (Ft. MJG, Paul Wall, Pimp C, R. Kelly, Too $hort & Twista)

description.plain: A remix featuring a respectable amount of hip hop artists. The song talks about them falling in love with the strippers at a strip club and fantasizing about them, where T-Pain was a previous victim in his original 2005 release of his duet version featuring American rapper Mike Jones as the only featured artist. Its song lyrics were controversial at the time of its release, leading to a censored version renamed “I’m In Luv (Wit' a Dancer)”, denoting the stripper’s erotic moves as ‘dancing’.

songs.full_title: Textin' My Ex by T-Pain (Ft. Tiffany Evans)
songs.title: Textin’ My Ex

description.plain:
In “Textin My Ex”, T-Pain recruits singer-songwriter Tiffany Evans and he shares how much he misses his former flame and his struggle to get over her.

During an interview with Complex, he spoke about the song:

There nothing more nerve-wrecking than watching those three dots mocking the fuck out of you for 20 minutes, then it’s just … ‘kk’.

songs.full_title: Wake Up Dead by T-Pain (Ft. Chris Brown)
songs.title: Wake Up Dead

description.plain:
In Wake Up Dead T-Pain and Chris Brown sing about the prospect of losing their lover and compare the feeling of losing them to death.

The name of the song was inspired by a scene in the movie Scary Movie 3 in a conversation between the character ‘CJ’ and ‘Mahalik’, as Chris Brown posted the scene on his Instagram Page shortly after announcing the song’s release.

Wake Up Dead is T-Pain and Chris Brown’s 7th career collaboration.

songs.full_title: Chopped N Skrewed by T-Pain (Ft. Ludacris)
songs.title: Chopped N Skrewed

description.plain:
In “Chopped N Skrewed”, Pain recruits Atlanta rapper Ludacris to collaborate to talk about their relationships. Hence the name, Pain’s significant other plays him and he doesn’t like it.

This is the second Pain and Ludacris collaboration. They both collaborated on Luda’s song “One More Drink”.
